title: Adult with Longstanding Sensorineural Hearing Loss Seeking Upgrade
chief_complaint: I need to upgrade my hearing aids because they are about 7 years old. I am in graduate school and want new technology that connects directly to my cell phone without extra accessories.

problem_summary.course: Stable; consistent use of amplification since diagnosis.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Relies on amplification for communication; currently in graduate school.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Specific interest in direct-to-cell phone connectivity.

history.present_illness: Patient reports consistent use of amplification since age 3. Currently wears 7-year-old hearing aids. Reports bilateral tinnitus. Denies dizziness or aural fullness.
history.otologic_history: Diagnosed with hearing loss at age 3.
history.prior_management: Used FM system with hearing aid until 8th grade. Used hearing aids alone through high school and college.
history.patient_goals: Upgrade technology for direct streaming connectivity.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral normal sloping to profound sensorineural hearing loss. The loss is normal/mild in the low frequencies (250-500 Hz) and drops precipitously to profound levels by 4000-8000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT is significantly better than PTA due to the precipitous slope of the hearing loss (SRT aligns with best thresholds). Word recognition is fair in the right ear and good in the left ear.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Absent ipsilateral and contralateral reflexes from 500 to 4000 Hz. Reflex decay could not be measured.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a bilateral, symmetrical, normal sloping to profound sensorineural hearing loss. Speech Reception Thresholds (25 dB HL) align with the best hearing thresholds rather than the Pure Tone Average due to the steep slope. Word recognition scores indicate fair to good discrimination ability at suprathreshold levels despite the severity of high-frequency loss.
counseling_points: Your hearing test confirms you have excellent low-pitch hearing that drops off sharply in the high pitches.
The discrepancy between your speech threshold (25 dB) and tone average (45-47 dB) is normal for this type of 'ski-slope' hearing loss.
Given your goals for graduate school, new hearing aids with direct-to-phone streaming are a great option.
We recommend Receiver-in-the-Canal (RIC) aids with custom canal molds to provide enough power for the high frequencies while keeping the fit comfortable.
notes_for_actor: You are a motivated 24-year-old graduate student.
You are very familiar with hearing aids, having worn them since age 3.
You are tech-savvy and specifically want to eliminate the need for extra accessories (like a streamer) to talk on your phone.
You do not have dizziness, but you do have ringing in your ears (tinnitus).
